material.mattext: I have read (or someone has read to me) the consent form and I am aware that I am being asked to participate in a research study. I have had the opportunity to ask questions and have had them answered to my satisfaction. I voluntarily agree to participate in this study.
I agree to participate in this study.
No, I do not agree to participate in this study
Which of the following statements is true of Gauss’s Law?
The Gaussian surface is a not a physical object, but just a surface in space over which a person can take an integral
The Gaussian surface always has to have the same shape as the charge distribution, but the sizes can be different
The Gaussian surface is a real physical object that naturally surrounds all charged objects.
The Gaussian surface and the charge distribution are the same thing (size, shape, and meaning), but called different things in different contexts.
Which of the following is/are true, regarding Gauss's Law? Select all that are true.
(a) If you know the electric field everywhere in space, applying Gauss’s Law can directly tell you how much charge is in a specific region of space (although the math might be hard).
(b) Even if you know the electric field everywhere in space, that is not enough information for Gauss’s Law alone to tell you how much charge is in a specific region of space.
(c) If you know the charge in a certain region of space, Gauss’s Law can directly tell you the electric field everywhere in space (although the math might be hard).
(d) Even if you know the charge in a certain region of space, that is not enough information for Gauss’s law alone to tell you the electric field in the space around the charged particles.
(e) None of the above is true.
Which of the following statements is true of Gauss’s Law? Select only the best answer.
(a) Gauss’s law only holds for spherical charge distributions
(b) Gauss’s law only holds for spherical surfaces around spherical charge distributions
(c) Gauss’s law can hold true for many charge distributions, but only if the Gaussian surface is spherical
(d) Gauss’s law can hold true for many charge distributions and many shapes of Gaussian surfaces, but it is only true if the charge distribution and the Gaussian surface have the same shape.
(e) Gauss’s law only holds true if the charge distribution and the Gaussian surface have the same axes of symmetry
(f) Gauss’s law holds for any smooth surface closed around any distribution of charge

Part of a long, straight, positively-charged rod is shown below. Assume the rod is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation for our purposes. Listed below are several Gaussian surfaces that could be used to enclose part of the charge on this rod. Select ALL the surfaces for which Gauss's law would hold: .
A sphere, centered on the origin
A sphere, centered away from the origin
A cube, centered on the origin
A cube, centered away from the origin
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the rod
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis perpendicular to the rod
A cylinder, centered away from the origin, its axis parallel to the rod

Part of a long, straight, positively-charged rod is shown below. Assume the rod is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation for our purposes. Which of the following describe(s) a Gaussian surface that would be USEFUL (involving relatively little work) in determining the electric field near the rod. Select all that might be useful.
A sphere, centered on the origin
A sphere, centered away from the origin
A cube, centered on the origin
A cube, centered away from the origin
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the rod
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis perpendicular to the rod
A cylinder, centered away from the origin, its axis parallel to the rod

A small, positively-charged particle is shown below. Listed below are several Gaussian surfaces that could be used to enclose the charged particle. Select ALL the surfaces for which Gauss's law would hold: .
A sphere, centered on the origin
A sphere, centered away from the origin
A cube, centered on the origin
A cube, centered away from the origin
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the z axis
A cylinder, centered away from the origin, its axis parallel to the z axis
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the x axis

A small, positively-charged particle is shown below. Which of the following describe(s) a Gaussian surface that would be USEFUL (requiring relatively little work) in determining the electric field around the particle, if you did not already know it. Select all that might be useful.
A sphere, centered on the origin
A sphere, centered away from the origin
A cube, centered on the origin
A cube, centered away from the origin
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the z axis
A cylinder, centered away from the origin, its axis parallel to the z axis
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the x axis
A point-like charged particle is shown below, surrounded by a Gaussian surface. What is the approximate direction of the electric field at point P?
A point-like charged particle is shown below, surrounded by a Gaussian surface. What is the approximate direction of the normal vector at point P?
A point-like charged particle is shown below, surrounded by a Gaussian surface. Which of the following statements is true? Select the best option.
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is zero degrees everywhere on this surface
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is 180 degrees everywhere on this surface
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is never zero anywhere on this surface
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is zero degrees in a couple of places, but not in general
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is either zero or 90 degrees everywhere on this surface

The next few questions relate to the charge distribution and Gaussian surface shown below. A positively-charged rod is shown (in red), and part of it is enclosed by a cylindrical Gaussian surface (displayed in semi-transparent green). Assume that the rod is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation. Assume the rod is the only charged object nearby.

What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point
What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point
What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point
What is the approximate angle in degrees between the electric field at point P and the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
One of these vectors does not exist at P

Label the flat, circular top (bottom) of the Gaussian surface "Top" ("Bottom"), and label the curved surface making up the side of the cylinder "Side". Call the radius of the cylinder and call its height . Which of the following expressions is/are correct? Select all that are correct.
(e)
(f)
(g)
(h)
(i)
(j)
(k)

The next few questions relate to the charge distribution and Gaussian surface shown below. A positively-charged rod is shown (in red), and part of it is enclosed by a cubic Gaussian surface (displayed in semi-transparent green). The rod passes exactly through the centers of the top and bottom faces of the cubic surface. Assume that the rod is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation. Assume the rod is the only charged object nearby.

The point P is near the upper right corner of the front face (but not quite on the corner). What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point

The point P is at the top face, just to the left of the rod.

What is the approximate angle in degrees between the electric field at point P and the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
One of these vectors does not exist at P

Here we refer to the faces of the cube as "top", "bottom", and we specifically refer to the sum of vertical faces as "all sides". Call the side length of the cube . Which of the following expressions is/are correct? Select all that are correct.

There should be a cardboard or plastic headset/goggles near you. If you know that you get headaches or nausea from virtual reality simulations, or do not wish to participate in viewing through the goggles for any reason, please inform the instructor. There will be NO penalty for informing the instructor of this. You will simply be given a different task. If you continue with the virtual reality, you will see a visualization of an electric field in stereoscopic 3D. When you are ready to go on, click on "continue" below

Hold the goggles up to your eyes and follow the instructions. There will be several scenes for you to view, each involving a charge distribution and a Gaussian surface. Clicking the small silver button on top of the goggles advances from one scene to the next. Between visualizations you will be prompted to return to Canvas to answer questions and/or receive instructions. The entire visualization will take approximately 5 minutes.

You are about to view scene 1, in which you will see a cylindrical Gaussian surface. It is green, and semi-transparent. There does not need to be a charge distribution in order for us to imagine a surface in space. But we will add a charge distribution later. The surface is semi-transparent so you can see any charge that is later added, inside. As you view scene 1, think about the direction of the normal vectors of this surface. Would you be able to verbally describe the direction(s) to a friend? When you finished viewing scene 1, return here to Canvas and click “continue”.
Scene 1 showed a cylindrical Gaussian surface, like the one shown below. What is the approximate direction of the normal vector at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 1 and once more to begin scene 2. The normal vector can be specified for any point on the Gaussian surface. In scene 2, we will only show a normal vector at a few points. As you view this scene, consider for what geometry of charge distribution might this Gaussian surface be useful. When you are finished viewing scene 2, return here to Canvas and click “continue”.

Scene 2 displayed a cylindrical Gaussian surface similar to the one below. For which of the following charge distributions would this Gaussian surface be USEFUL (involving relatively little work) in determining the electric field on the surface? Choose all that apply.
A solid spherical charge, centered on the origin
A solid spherical charge, centered away from the origin
A cubic charge, centered on the origin
A cubic charge, centered away from the origin
A short charged rod, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to z
A short charged rod, centered on the origin, its axis perpendicular to z
A long charged rod, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to z
A long charged rod, centered away from the origin, its axis parallel to z

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 2 and once more to begin scene 3. In scene 3, we add in a long, uniformly-charged rod. Clearly it is not infinitely long, but assume it is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation. We do not yet show the electric field around this rod. As you view scene 3, consider in what direction(s) the electric field vectors should point. When you are finished viewing scene 3, return here to Canvas and click "continue".
Scene 3 showed the long charged rod and Gaussian cylinder below. What is the approximate direction of the electric field vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 3 and once more to begin scene 4. In scene 4, we will show you the electric field vectors at some points around the charged rod. The electric field actually exists at all points in space, but we display white electric field vectors at only a few points around the rod. As you view scene 4, consider the relative direction of the electric fields and the normal vectors. When you are finished viewing scene 4, return here to Canvas and click "continue".

Scene four showed the direction of the electric field and the normal vectors at a few points. What is the approximate angle in degrees between the electric field at point P and the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
One of these vectors does not exist at P

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 4 and once more to begin scene 5. Now we will change the position of the Gaussian surface, and we will show only the electric field vectors at points on the Gaussian surface. All else will be same. Once again look at the relative direction between the normal vectors and the electric field vectors. Consider what might be good or bad about this in terms of applying Gauss's Law. When you are finished viewing scene 5, return here to Canvas and click "continue".

The contents of scene 5 are roughly reproduced below. The figure shows a charged rod surrounded by a Gaussian surface, which is now shifted to the right. Which of the following statements below is true? Select the best option.
Gauss's Law still holds for this surface, and this surface is still useful for determining the electric field
Gauss's Law still holds for this surface, but this surface is not really useful for determining the electric field
Gauss's Law no longer holds for this surface, but this surface could still useful for determining the electric field
Gauss's Law no longer holds for this surface, and this surface is not useful for determining the electric field

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 5 and once more to begin scene 6. Now we will move the Gaussian surface further to the side. Look at the relative direction between the normal vectors and the electric field vectors. Consider whether the total flux might be positive, negative, or zero. When you are finished viewing scene 6, return here to Canvas and click "continue".
As in scene 6, the figure below shows a Gaussian surface shifted to the right, near a charged rod. Which of the following statements below is true? Select the best option.
The total electric flux through the Gaussian surface is positive
The total electric flux through the Gaussian surface is negative
The total electric flux through the Gaussian surface is zero
Not enough information is given to determine the sign of the flux

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 6 and once more to begin scene 7. Now we will change the shape of the Gaussian surface. The charged rod, normal vectors, and electric field vectors will all be displayed, and the color scheme will be unchanged. With the new Gaussian surface, again look at the relative direction between the normal vectors and the electric field vectors. Consider what might be good or bad about this in terms of applying Gauss's Law. When you are finished viewing scene 7, return here to Canvas and click "continue".
The contents of scene 7 are roughly reproduced below. The figure shows a charged rod surrounded by a cubic Gaussian surface. Which of the following statements below is true? Select the best option.
Normal vectors and Electric fields are parallel everywhere on this Gaussian surface
Normal vectors and Electric fields are either parallel or perpendicul everywhere on this Gaussian surface
Normal vectors and electric fields are perpendicular everywhere on this Gaussian surface
Normal vectors and electric fields are neither parallel nor perpendicular to each other on much of this Gaussian surface
There is not enough information to determine whether electric fields and normal vectors are parallel or perpendicular to each other

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 7 and once more to begin scene 8. Scene 8 will show you the same charge distribution, but now there will be two different Gaussian surfaces for you to compare. Consider how they are alike or different in terms of the role they play in Gauss’s Law. When you are finished viewing scene 8, return here to Canvas and click "continue".
As in scene 8, two Gaussian cylinders are shown below. Call the smaller (inner) surface A, and the larger (outer) surface B. Which of the following statements below is true? Select the best option.
The flux through A and B is the same, and the charge enclosed by A and B is the same.
The flux through A and B is the same, but the charges enclosed by A and B are different.
The fluxes through A and B are different, but the charge enclosed by A and B is the same.
The fluxes through A and B are different, and the charges enclosed by A and B are different.
There is not enough information to relate the fluxes and/or charges enclosed.

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 8 and once more to begin scene 9. Scene 9 will again show you two different Gaussian surfaces for you to compare. Consider how they are alike or different in terms of the role they play in Gauss’s Law. When you are finished viewing scene 9, return here to Canvas and click "continue".

As in scene 9, two Gaussian cylinders are shown below. Call the centered (lighter) surface A, and the off-center (darker) surface B. Which of the following statements below is true? Select the best option.
The flux through A and B is the same, and the charge enclosed by A and B is the same.
The flux through A and B is the same, but the charges enclosed by A and B are different.
The fluxes through A and B are different, but the charge enclosed by A and B is the same.
The fluxes through A and B are different, and the charges enclosed by A and B are different.
There is not enough information to relate the fluxes and/or charges enclosed.

In a moment, return to the goggles and click once to end scene 9 and once more to begin scene 10. Scene 10 will again show you two different Gaussian surfaces for you to compare. Consider how they are alike or different in terms of the role they play in Gauss’s Law. When you are finished viewing scene 10, return here to Canvas and click "continue".
As in scene 10, two Gaussian surfaces are shown below: one cubic and one cylindrical. Which of the following statements below is true? Select the best option.
The flux through the cylinder and cube are the same, and the charge enclosed by each is the same.
The flux through the cylinder and cube are the same, but the charges enclosed by each are different.
The fluxes through the cylinder and cube are different, but the charge enclosed by each is the same.
The fluxes through the cylinder and cube are different, and the charges enclosed by each are different.
There is not enough information to determine the relative fluxes and enclosed charges.

The next few questions relate to the charge distribution and Gaussian surface shown below. A positively-charged plate is shown (in red), and part of it is enclosed by a cylindrical Gaussian surface (displayed in semi-transparent green). Only part of the plate is shown; assume that the entire plate is so long that treating it as infinite (in both x and y directions) is a good approximation. Assume the plate is the only charged object nearby.

What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P, which is on the curved side of the cylinder? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P, which is on the left vertical side of the cylinder? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point
A point-like charged particle is shown below, surrounded by a Gaussian surface. Which of the following statements is true? Select the best option.
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is zero degrees everywhere on this surface
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is either zero or 90 degrees everywhere on this surface
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is never zero anywhere on this surface
The angle between the normal vector and the electric field is zero degrees in a couple of places, but not in general
A point-like charged particle is shown below, surrounded by a Gaussian surface. What is the approximate direction of the normal vector at point P?
A point-like charged particle is shown below, surrounded by a Gaussian surface. What is the approximate direction of the electric field at point P?

The next few questions relate to the charge distribution and Gaussian surface shown below. A positively-charged rod is shown (in red), and part of it is enclosed by a cylindrical Gaussian surface (displayed in semi-transparent green). Assume that the rod is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation. Assume the rod is the only charged object nearby.

What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point
What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point
What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point

Label the flat, circular top (bottom) of the Gaussian surface "Top" ("Bottom"), and label the curved surface making up the side of the cylinder "Side". Call the radius of the cylinder and call its height . Which of the following expressions is/are correct? Select all that are correct.

The next few questions relate to the charge distribution and Gaussian surface shown below. A positively-charged rod is shown (in red), and part of it is enclosed by a cubic Gaussian surface (displayed in semi-transparent green). The rod passes exactly through the centers of the top and bottom faces of the cubic surface. Assume that the rod is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation. Assume the rod is the only charged object nearby.

The point P is near the upper right corner of the front face (but not quite on the corner). What is the approximate direction of the electric field at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no electric field at this point
What is the approximate direction of the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
There is no normal vector at this point
What is the approximate angle in degrees between the electric field at point P and the normal vector of the surface at the point P? Select the best answer.
One of these vectors does not exist at P

Here we refer to the faces of the cube as "top", "bottom", and we specifically refer to the sum of vertical faces as "all sides". Call the side length of the cube . Which of the following expressions is/are correct? Select all that are correct.

Part of a long, straight, positively-charged rod is shown below. Assume the rod is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation for our purposes. Which of the following describe(s) a Gaussian surface that would be USEFUL (involving relatively little work) in determining the electric field near the rod. Select all that might be useful.
A sphere, centered on the origin
A sphere, centered away from the origin
A cube, centered on the origin
A cube, centered away from the origin
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the rod
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis perpendicular to the rod
A cylinder, centered away from the origin, its axis parallel to the rod

Part of a long, straight, positively-charged rod is shown below. Assume the rod is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation for our purposes. Listed below are several Gaussian surfaces that could be used to enclose part of the charge on this rod. Select ALL the surfaces for which Gauss's law would hold: .
A sphere, centered on the origin
A sphere, centered away from the origin
A cube, centered on the origin
A cube, centered away from the origin
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the rod
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis perpendicular to the rod
A cylinder, centered away from the origin, its axis parallel to the rod

Consider the spherical charge distribution below: a positive charge Q distributed uniformly throughout the volume of a sphere of radius R, centered on the origin. You need to choose a Guassian surface such that Gauss’s Law will be USEFUL (requiring relatively little work) in finding information about the electric field. Which of the following statements is most accurate about choosing a USEFUL Gaussian surface?
(a) A spherical Gaussian surface of radius r<R, and only if it is centered on the origin.
(b) A spherical Gaussian surface of radius r>R, and only if it is centered on the origin.
(c) A spherical Gaussian surface of any radius, but only if it is centered on the origin.
(d) A spherical Gaussian surface of radius r<R, and it can be centered on any point.
(e) A spherical Gaussian surface of radius r>R, and if can be centered on any point.
(f) A spherical Gaussian surface of any radius, and it can be centered on any point.

Part of a very large, positively-charged plate is shown below. Although only part of it is shown, assume the plate is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation for our purposes. Which of the following describe(s) a Gaussian surface that would be USEFUL (requiring relatively little work) in determining the electric field near the plate. Select all that might be useful.
A sphere, centered on the origin
A sphere, centered slightly away from the origin
A cube, centered on the origin, with two faces parallel to the plate
A cube, centered slightly away from the origin, with two faces parallel to the plate
A cube, centered on the origin, with zero faces parallel to the plate
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the z axis
A cylinder, centered slightly away from the origin, its axis parallel to the z axis
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the x axis

Part of a very large, positively-charged plate is shown below. Assume the plate is so long that treating it as infinite is a good approximation for our purposes. Listed below are several Gaussian surfaces that could be used to enclose part of the charge on this plate. Select ALL the surfaces for which Gauss's law would hold: .
A sphere, centered on the origin
A sphere, centered slightly away from the origin
A cube, centered on the origin, with two faces parallel to the plate
A cube, centered slightly away from the origin, with two faces parallel to the plate
A cube, centered on the origin, with zero faces parallel to the plate
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the z axis
A cylinder, centered slightly away from the origin, its axis parallel to the z axis
A cylinder, centered on the origin, its axis parallel to the x axis
Which of the following statements is true of Gauss’s Law?
The Gaussian surface is a not a physical object, but just a surface in space over which a person can take an integral
The Gaussian surface always has to have the same shape as the charge distribution, but the sizes can be different
The Gaussian surface is a real physical object that naturally surrounds all charged objects.
The Gaussian surface and the charge distribution are the same thing (size, shape, and meaning), but called different things in different contexts.
Which of the following is/are true, regarding Gauss's Law? Select all that are true.
(a) If you know the electric field everywhere in space, applying Gauss’s Law can directly tell you how much charge is in a specific region of space (although the math might be hard).
(b) Even if you know the electric field everywhere in space, that is not enough information for Gauss’s Law alone to tell you how much charge is in a specific region of space.
(c) If you know the charge in a certain region of space, Gauss’s Law can directly tell you the electric field everywhere in space (although the math might be hard).
(d) Even if you know the charge in a certain region of space, that is not enough information for Gauss’s law alone to tell you the electric field in the space around the charged particles.
(e) None of the above is true.
Which of the following statements is true of Gauss’s Law? Select only the best answer.
(a) Gauss’s law only holds for spherical charge distributions
(b) Gauss’s law only holds for spherical surfaces around spherical charge distributions
(c) Gauss’s law can hold true for many charge distributions, but only if the Gaussian surface is spherical
(d) Gauss’s law can hold true for many charge distributions and many shapes of Gaussian surfaces, but it is only true if the charge distribution and the Gaussian surface have the same shape.
(e) Gauss’s law only holds true if the charge distribution and the Gaussian surface have the same axes of symmetry
(f) Gauss’s law holds for any smooth surface closed around any distribution of charge
Around the middle of the assessment, you were asked to view some visual aid related to electric fields. Please indicate how helpful you felt this visual aid was.
Did you find the use of the visual aid enjoyable?
Would you recommend the visual aid you had to a friend?
At this point in your life, how often do you play video games?
Have you used a stereoscopic virtual reality device before (such as Google Cardboard, Occulus Rift or PlayStation VR)?
When you were younger, about how often did you play video games?
Before today, have you used a stereoscopic Virtual Reality device (such as Google Cardboard, Occulus Rift, or PlayStation VR)?
I prefer not to answer this question

conditionvar.varequal: I prefer not to answer this question
